Description: Egyptian terracotta model sword or dagger. A model of a sheathed sword, with a ribbed handle with triple-balled pommel, impressed with four small circles, perhaps indicating a fourth ball; the guard is of truncated pedimental form, enclosing a six-pointed rosette in relief; the lower moulding is crossed by diagonal grooves. The scabbard is plain. Very summary treatment at the back. Apparently solid, from two-piece mould. Brown Nile silt with a reddish core and abundant fine gold mica and white inclusions.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), Site 95 (Petrie), the terracotta workshop, at the eastern edge of the town
Curator's comments: Locally made at Site 95 in terracotta workshop noted in 1885 at the eastern edge of the city. BM1886,0401.1444, 1886,0401.1451-2, 1886,0401.1537-40, 1886,0401.1574 and 1888,0601.108 were found together at this terracottas workshop (Petrie 1886: 45). Petrie dates this workshop to about the end of the 1st century AD, Bailey 3rd to 2nd century BC. A similar sword was found at Memphis (Petrie Museum uc47929). Parallel found in the Fayum, now in Cairo Museum (TR6/3/36/1=SR5/1134). 'Site 95' written on the object in pencil. Site 95 is the terracotta workshop, found by sebakhin in 1885, at the eastern edge of the city. Found by sebakhin.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (C631)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DF.02) (Phase 1)
